0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (through age 55 years) 0.5 mL IM single dose (manufacturer dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (through age 55 years with high-risk conditions) 0.5 mL IM as 2-dose series, given at least 2 months apart (guideline dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (revaccination of adults who remain at increased risk for infection) 0.5 mL IM every 5 years
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (56 years or older, revaccination of person previously vaccinated with Menactra(R)) 0.5 mL IM

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (9 to 23 months of age): 0.5 mL IM as 2-dose series, given at least 3 months apart (manufacturer dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (9 months through 23 months of age with persistent complement component deficiency, who have not received a complete vaccine series) 2-dose series, given at least 12 weeks apart
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (2 years or older with high-risk conditions, who have not received a complete vaccine series) 2-dose series, given at least 8 weeks apart; for children with asplenia, including sickle cell disease, administer vaccination at least 4 weeks following the completion of the 13-valent pneumococcal vaccine series (guideline dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (2 years or older) 0.5 mL IM single dose (manufacturer dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (11 through 12 years) give single dose followed by a booster dose at age 16 years (guideline dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: (11 through 18 years, with HIV) 2-dose series, given at least 8 weeks apart (guideline dose)
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: Catch-up: Administer at 13 to 18 years if not previously vaccinated (guideline dose).
  • Meningococcal infectious disease; Prophylaxis: Catch-up: If first dose given at age 13 to 15 years, give booster dose at age 16 to 18 years, allowing at least 8 weeks between doses; if first dose is given at age 16 years or older, a booster dose is not required (guideline dose).

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: severe allergic reaction (eg, anaphylaxis) following a previous dose of a meningococcal capsular polysaccharide-, diphtheria toxoid-, or CRM197-containing vaccine, or to any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions, including immediate reactions and anaphylaxis may occur; appropriate supportive medical treatment should be readily available during treatment
  • acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS), history; may increase risk of GBS following vaccination
  • immunocompromised patients, including those receiving concomitant immunosuppressant therapy (eg, irradiation, antimetabolites, alkylating agents, cytotoxic agents, and corticosteroids used in greater than physiologic doses); may have a diminished vaccine response
  • report suspected adverse events to VAERS at 1-800-822-7967 or http://vaers.hhs.gov

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (10.9% to 21.8% (age 2 to 55 years); 30% (age 9 to 12 months)), Injection site induration (15.7% to 18.9% (age 2 to 55 years)), Injection site pain (45% to 59.2% (age 2 to 55 years); 48.5% (age 12 months); 37.4% (age 9 months)), Swelling at injection site (10.8% to 17.4% (age 9 months to 55 years))
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (11.1% to 16% (age 2 to 55 years)), Loss of appetite (8.2% to 11.8% (age 2 to 55 years); 35.7% (age 12 months); 30.2% (age 9 months)), Vomiting (11% (age 12 months); 14.1% (age 9 months))
  • Musculoskeletal:Arthralgia (6.8% to 19.8% (age 2 to 55 years))
  • Neurologic:Headache (35.6% to 41.4% (age 11 to 55 years)), Somnolence (10.8% (age 2 to 10 years); 39.8% (age 12 months); 30.2% (age 9 months))
  • Psychiatric:Crying, excessive (40% (age 12 months); 33.3% (age 9 months))
  • Other:Fatigue (30% to 34.7% (age 11 to 55 years)), Fever (1.5% to 5.2% (age 2 to 55 years); 24.5% (age 12 months); 12.2% (age 9 months)), Irritability (12.4% (age 2 to 10 years); 64.8% (age 12 months); 56.8% (age 9 months)), Malaise (21.9% to 23.6% (age 11 to 55 years))

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Diphtheria toxoid conjugate vaccine is a quadrivalent meningococcal vaccine that confers active immunity by stimulating the production of antibodies against capsular polysaccharide antigens of Neisseria meningitidis serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 conjugated to the diphtheria toxoid protein.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for IM use only; do not give subQ or IV
  • Intramuscular
    • do not mix with other vaccines in the same syringe; use separate syringes at separate injection sites
    • (children 2 years or older with functional or anatomic asplenia) interval of at least 4 weeks between completion of 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine series and receipt of Menactra(R) meningococcal conjugate vaccine

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This vaccine may cause injection site pain or tenderness, irritability, diarrhea, drowsiness, loss of appetite, headache, and fatigue.
  • Instruct parents/guardians and/or patients to immediately report signs/symptoms of allergic reaction or Guillain-Barre syndrome (eg, muscle weakness, numbness, tingling).
